question.title: Running JavaFX Application on JRE 8u451 After JavaFX Removal
question.body:
I'm facing an issue with a JavaFX application written for JDK 8. My company recently updated to JRE 8u451, and the application no longer runs because JavaFX has been removed from this release. I have access to the source code and can rebuild the project, but rewriting the application to use Swing or AWT, as Oracle suggests, is not an option. Additionally, upgrading to OpenJFX/OpenJDK (e.g., JavaFX 24 with Oracle JDK 24) is not feasible due to corporate restrictions: we cannot install third-party software, and executable files are limited to a whitelist.

The error I get is:

Error: JavaFX has been removed from JDK 8. Visit https://www.oracle.com/javase/javafx for more information.

Oracle recommends migrating to Swing or AWT, or taking advantage of the latest feature set available in JavaFX 24 (via the OpenJFX project at OpenJDK) on Oracle JDK 24. We have provided a guide on the OpenJFX wiki to assist developers familiar with JavaFX 8 who have not yet removed the dependency.

Oracle JDK 8u451, released on April 15, 2025, is the first Oracle JDK 8 release that does not include JavaFX.

Here’s my Gradle project setup:

plugins {
    id 'java'
}

group = 'com.company.app'
version = '1.0.3'

repositories {
    mavenCentral()
}

java {
    sourceCompatibility = JavaVersion.VERSION_1_8
    targetCompatibility = JavaVersion.VERSION_1_8
}

dependencies {
    compileOnly 'org.projectlombok:lombok:1.18.38'
    annotationProcessor 'org.projectlombok:lombok:1.18.38'
    implementation 'org.postgresql:postgresql:42.7.5'
    implementation 'org.yaml:snakeyaml:2.4'
    testImplementation platform('org.junit:junit-bom:5.10.0')
    testImplementation 'org.junit.jupiter:junit-jupiter'
    testAnnotationProcessor 'org.projectlombok:lombok:1.18.38'
    testCompileOnly 'org.projectlombok:lombok:1.18.38'
}

jar {
    def jars = configurations.runtimeClasspath.files.collect { "lib/$it.name" }

    destinationDirectory = layout.buildDirectory.dir('libs/app')

    manifest {
        attributes('Main-Class': 'com.company.app.App',
                'Class-Path': jars.join(" ")
        )
    }
}

Given these constraints, is there a way to restore the JavaFX functionality in my project? For example, can I include JavaFX libraries from an earlier JDK 8 release (e.g., 8u441) in my build, or is there another approach to make the application run on JRE 8u451 without violating corporate policies?

Any help or guidance would be greatly appreciated!

question_comments.body: Might be a fool's errand, but with lots of faff you could try and build javafxrt.jar against 8u451: wiki.openjdk.org/display/OpenJFX/Building+OpenJFX+8u

@ThomasTimbul I tried following AI's advice — take the libraries he suggested from my JDK and put them as dependencies for the project. But that didn't help. I know AIs like to hallucinate, so I decided to ask people for help.

@EdwardNorthwind "can I include JavaFX libraries from an earlier JDK 8 release (e.g., 8u441) in my build" - Have you tried this? If you can get the .jar files out of the previous release, they should be binary compatible with 8u451. Assuming you are allowed to bundle 3rd party libs with your Java app (roll eyes at corporate numpties)

Yes, that's right, it's not what works for me. If I could, I'd just build a modular application with JRE 21 built in. But Windows group policies are blocking it from running. I guess I'm out of options here, and I have to rewrite the GUI to Swing/SWT/AWT.
Azul provide some advice on your options. It is not the answer you want, but the linked post does explain the situation well enough IMO.

If your corporation is a paying customer of Oracle, (a) Oracle may be able to provide a private edition of Java 8 bundled with JavaFX, (b) Your support plan with Oracle may also cover technical support of JavaFX/OpenJFX, which is another point to include on your sales pitch to expand the whitelist.
Hmmm… Oracle did publicly promise to “support JavaFX with new fixes for Java SE 8 until at least March 2025”. See last page of their white paper, Java Client Roadmap Update.

You can petition the corporate powers that be to add OpenJFX to the whitelist. Tips: Talk to the right persons in asking, do your research to show how well tested is OpenJFX, and stress that it is backed by Oracle officially (co-led, actually) and that it is open-source which means more eyeballs on it. And technically they already had approved JavaFX indirectly by approving the earlier releases of JDK 8. And OpenJFX is part of the OpenJDK project owned and led by Oracle. That’s a pretty easy sell if you reach the right folks.

“Additionally, upgrading to OpenJFX/OpenJDK is not feasible due to corporate restrictions”  Then your company does not permit using a secure version of Java with JavaFX.  That’s the reality unless and until they make an exception in their policy.  Once you inform them of this, it’s their problem, not yours.
What is the company policy about using newer LTS Oracle JDKs like Oracle Java 21?

@Abra Thanks for the suggestion! Unfortunately, I can’t install any software, including non-Oracle JDKs, due to corporate restrictions. Oracle JRE 8u451 is pre-installed on client PCs, which is why we use Java for development—third-party software is prohibited, but JRE is allowed since it’s provided by the company. I need a way to restore JavaFX functionality on JRE 8u451, possibly by bundling JavaFX libraries from an earlier Oracle JDK 8 release or another workaround. Any ideas?
There are [non-Oracle] JDKs that include JavaFX. I know of three: Azul, Liberica and OpenLogic. Make sure you download the version that includes JavaFX. Are any of those feasible?
